keyFacts: This is a federal contract for a $698,108.99 camera surveillance system at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York, awarded on September 21, 2018.
The contractor is SigNet Technologies, Inc., and the contracting agency is the Federal Bureau of Prisons.
The system includes hundreds of cameras, video recorders, encoders, decoders, and servers from the 'Nice Vision' product line.
Jeff Colton is named as the Facilities Manager and Contracting Officer's Representative (COR) for MCC New York, responsible for overseeing the contract.
The document includes extensive standard government contract clauses covering security, hazardous materials, personnel vetting (HSPD-12 compliance), and residency requirements for contractors.
The document defines 'DOJ Information' as any information owned, produced, or controlled by the Department of Justice, including personal identifiable information (PII).
Contractors are prohibited from disclosing DOJ Information to third parties and must use it solely for contract performance, with all deliverables becoming U.S. Government property.
Contractors must comply with extensive federal IT security standards (FISMA, NIST, FIPS) and obtain an Authority to Operate (ATO) for any system processing DOJ data.
Confirmed security breaches must be reported to the DOJ within 1 hour of discovery, and potential breaches within 72 hours, with detailed reporting requirements.

The clause includes specific rules for cloud computing, requiring FedRAMP certification or DOJ authorization, and mandates that contractors ensure the DOJ can retrieve its data from cloud systems within 48 hours.
The contract requires contractor performance evaluation via the Contractor Performance Assessment Reporting System (CPARS), a Department of Defense web-based system.
All electronic and information technology procured must comply with Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (as amended) for accessibility standards.
Contract funds cannot be awarded to corporations convicted of a felony under Federal law within the preceding 24 months, unless the agency determines suspension/debarment is unnecessary.

Contract funds cannot be awarded to corporations with unpaid Federal tax liabilities that have been assessed and for which remedies are exhausted, unless the agency determines suspension/debarment is unnecessary.
The contractor must flow down these clauses to all subcontractors and cloud service providers (CSPs), with any breach by them attributed to the contractor.
